text: hi everyone Anthony Fantino here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new Big Ups
album 18 hours of static New York Bands
big ups this is their debut full-length
album which they have built up to with
from what I understand a split a 7-inch
and it's a record that I love the more I
listen to it there's a lot of noisy punk
rock on this record a bit of old-school
lo-fi indie rock as well and with these
influences the band essentially delivers
a series of songs they have some really
strong in-your-face very opinionated
lyrical content reflections on the world
at large the fast pace of life really
spittin some big fat loogies into some
societal norms it's angry its rebellious
and it's looking for the first person
that's gonna give us some crap because
right away it's gonna say hey I'm not
gonna take this crap the band might seem
like they're kind of looking for a fight
but at least they choose their battles
wisely the song wall being about what
seems like self trickery the lyrics sing
about pulling the wool over one's own
eyes on the slow burner of a track that
features some guitar leads and some
vocal deliveries that sound pretty akin
to something from like a slant record I
love the very tone down subdued verses
on this track and how they're matched
with a really passionate vocal delivery
on the chorus and the explosive finish
on this song too we should switch this
we've gotta get the drive Like Jehu in
here man for this one the lyrics on this
track and others here are very simple
they're straightforward the rhyme
schemes can be pretty basic as well
however the sentiments for the most part
do feel powerful I know there's a better
way but I just can't say what will make
it okay if I could have just one wish I
would wish for this I would wish for
justice or maybe my favorite lyric on
the entire album people say it's always
getting better all the time but it's bad
still bad I love the song disposer with
these very subdued guitars in the back
goes through this take-out-the-trash
mantra disposable camera disposable
razor disposable income disposable wife
everything we throw away the song is
essentially really quick to point out
how many things we buy into knowing that
we're just gonna be tossing them in the
trash months days weeks maybe years down
the road and the drum groove in the
background of this track is a little
funky to kind of in a Fugazi sort of way
the song atheist self-help is another
track on here that while the guitars the
drums are good they're punky they're
noisy we get some lyrics that are
satirical hilarious in a way where the
singer of the band is saying that you
know I don't need religious doctrine to
tell me what a jerk I am I sort of do
that pretty well on my own the song goes
black has all these speedy guitar riffs
and drums matched with these lyrics that
are just going a million miles an hour
talking about the fast pace of life and
how life is just going by so fast that
manat really living in the moment or
enjoying the little things in life then
there is the song TMI which essentially
sings about being a self medicating
emotionless numb to the world robot my
operating system runs on complacency I
think it's fine it doesn't really bother
me then every track on here pretty much
delivers a very plain as day message and
occasionally there are songs on here
that sort of segue into one another
really well really kind of feel like one
track or just complement one another
where one track sort of carries the
momentum of the one that came before it
like the song little kid which switches
right out of TMI with these insane
spiraling just dizzying noisy as hell
guitar riffs we're against them the
singer of the band is saying stop it
almost as if he's pleading with the
instrumentation itself as he is singing
and the sound of the record the sound of
the instrumentation on this thing is
just so great it's just so top-notch for
this kind of songwriting I mean the
guitars are so brittle the drums just
kind of get lost in the mess a little
bit the bass guitar is really guttural
it feels like every pick being stroked
onto the strings it's just like killing
the guitar and in a way that kind of
reminds me of Minor Threat the band toes
this line between being very fast
precise and sort of having just enough
looseness and enough chaos to just make
it feel like the group is just on the
verge of total destruction there's just
a rough around the edges quality to this
LP that I really like Plus for a record
this noisy the vocals are very readable
which again is great because messages do
play a pretty strong role on a majority
of the tracks here there's nothing too
esoteric about the lyrics on this LP and
while I think many of the tracks here
really are in your face with what
they're trying to say there is an
element of cleverness and and satire
that keeps these songs from feeling too
preachy or like they're trying to jump
down your throat or look down at you or
anything like that the downsides for me
on this record is that there are a few
songs on here there are a little short
of breath and don't really leave an
impact on me because of that or feature
such a simple lyrical approach that hmm
I'm left groaning a little bit like the
opener body parts or some of the verses
on the track wool other than that I
think this is a fantastic short little
noise punk record that has a lot to say
and will definitely go down as one of my
favorite rock records of the year I am
feeling a strong eight on this thing
transition if you've given this record a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it did you hate it why what do you
think I should review next and that's
about it
Anthony Fantana music review forever
